citations.narrative:
The outdoor enclosure housing one adult dog did not have adequate wind and rain breaks at the shelter entrance. The
primary shelter structure utilized a transport kennel that is placed adjacent to a supplemental shelter consisting of a tin
roof and two additional sides. Although the transport kennel provides a floor and roof, it does not offer a fourth side or rain
and wind breaks. The presence of these housing structures help protect the animals from inclement weather and
elements, especially wind and increased rainfall, allowing them to remain dry and warm. All shelters housing dogs in
outdoor facilities must contain a roof, four sides, a floor, and provide a wind break and rain break at the entrance to help
keep the animals dry and comfortable in their shelter.
Correct by July 6, 2023.

The outdoor enclosure housing one adult dog has a shelter structure constructed of wooden surfaces that are not
impervious to moisture. An additional shelter structure consisting of a tin roof and two unsealed, wooded sides has been
affixed to the kennel unit present in the primary enclosure. While the transport kennel unit is impervious to moisture, the
wooden surfaces of the supplementary housing structure is not resistant to water absorption.
Building structures made of unsealed wood cannot be properly cleaned or sanitized when permeable to moisture. The
licensee must ensure that all structures the animals come in contact with are impervious to moisture and able to be
readily cleaned and sanitized or removed/replaced once they become worn or soiled.
Correct by July 6, 2023.

The licensee’s program of veterinary care is incomplete with details pertaining to the puppy physical exams, parasite
control program and preventative care and treatment plan for healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails,
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth. While puppies at the facility currently receive their physical exams by the vet
during each annual kennel inspection, the program of veterinary care states that exams are preformed at one week of age
by the licensee.
In addition, the parasite control program and preventative care and treatment plan for healthy and un-matted hair coats,
properly trimmed nails, clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth do not outline the frequency schedule, testing, and
treatment plan for the aforementioned items, as required for the program of vet care. While the licensee notated that all of
these action items are 'examined periodically, and treating as needed', more details are needed to define how often the
dogs are checked for each item and any appropriate treatment plans.
Each dealer must keep and maintain an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian and includes details pertaining to the puppy physical exams, parasite
control programs and preventative care and treatment plans for healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails,
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth. The licensee must add the details listed above to the Program of Veterinary
Care and have it approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by July 19, 2023

Two adult dogs were observed on inspection with ongoing conditions. While both dogs are being monitored by the
licensee for hairless swellings in between their toes, neither concern has been documented by the facility. The inspectors
called the licensee’s veterinarian whom agreed monitoring was adequate for the conditions.
Failure to keep medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving
adequate veterinary care. Dealers must keep copies of medical records that include the date and description of the
problem identified, treatment procedure performed and plan for care, findings, and test results when appropriate.
Correct by July 6, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.4(b) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The outdoor enclosure housing one adult dog did not have adequate wind and rain breaks at the shelter entrance. The 
primary shelter structure utilized a transport kennel that is placed adjacent to a supplemental shelter consisting of a tin 
roof and two additional sides. Although the transport kennel provides a floor and roof, it does not offer a fourth side or rain 
and wind breaks. The presence of these housing structures help protect the animals from inclement weather and 
elements, especially wind and increased rainfall, allowing them to remain dry and warm. All shelters housing dogs in 
outdoor facilities must contain a roof, four sides, a floor, and provide a wind break and rain break at the entrance to help 
keep the animals dry and comfortable in their shelter. 
Correct by July 6, 2023. 
3.4(c) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The outdoor enclosure housing one adult dog has a shelter structure constructed of wooden surfaces that are not 
impervious to moisture. An additional shelter structure consisting of a tin roof and two unsealed, wooded sides has been 
affixed to the kennel unit present in the primary enclosure. While the transport kennel unit is impervious to moisture, the 
wooden surfaces of the supplementary housing structure is not resistant to water absorption. 
Building structures made of unsealed wood cannot be properly cleaned or sanitized when permeable to moisture. The 
licensee must ensure that all structures the animals come in contact with are impervious to moisture and able to be 
readily cleaned and sanitized or removed/replaced once they become worn or soiled. 
Correct by July 6, 2023. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee’s program of veterinary care is incomplete with details pertaining to the puppy physical exams, parasite 
control program and preventative care and treatment plan for healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, 
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth. While puppies at the facility currently receive their physical exams by the vet 
during each annual kennel inspection, the program of veterinary care states that exams are preformed at one week of age 
by the licensee. 
In addition, the parasite control program and preventative care and treatment plan for healthy and un-matted hair coats,

properly trimmed nails, clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth do not outline the frequency schedule, testing, and 
treatment plan for the aforementioned items, as required for the program of vet care. While the licensee notated that all of 
these action items are 'examined periodically, and treating as needed', more details are needed to define how often the 
dogs are checked for each item and any appropriate treatment plans. 
Each dealer must keep and maintain an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in 
writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian and includes details pertaining to the puppy physical exams, parasite 
control programs and preventative care and treatment plans for healthy and un-matted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, 
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin and teeth. The licensee must add the details listed above to the Program of Veterinary 
Care and have it approved by the attending veterinarian. 
Correct by July 19, 2023 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Two adult dogs were observed on inspection with ongoing conditions. While both dogs are being monitored by the 
licensee for hairless swellings in between their toes, neither concern has been documented by the facility. The inspectors 
called the licensee’s veterinarian whom agreed monitoring was adequate for the conditions. 
Failure to keep medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving 
adequate veterinary care. Dealers must keep copies of medical records that include the date and description of the 
problem identified, treatment procedure performed and plan for care, findings, and test results when appropriate. 
Correct by July 6, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
